articles.title: A Very Mild Alaska Prepares for Further Rain and Snow
articles.author: Dave Holder
articles.summary: The weather in Alaska has been very mild with numerous record-breaking warmth over the recent weeks. The pattern of late has been dictated by a strong upper-level ridge over the North Pacific. There are also repeated systems moving in from the south bringing abundant moisture to the area. Widespread winter alerts have been issued across the state, with the exception of Anchorage, where temperatures are too warm for accumulating snow.

articles.title: PM ‘worried' about the ‘scourge' of antisemitism
articles.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is worried about the increase in antisemitism in Australia. Mr Albanese told Sky News Political Editor Andrew Clennell that he's worried about any activity aimed at disrupting society.   He called the rise in anti-Semitism a scourge.

articles.title: Labor ‘underestimated' how long the war in Ukraine would last for
articles.summary: Labor "underestimated" the extent of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese told Sky News Political Editor Andrew Clennell. The impact of the war in Ukraine had a big impact on global inflation and energy prices, he said.

articles.title: Australia Day-Survival Day 2025: police officer honoured, citizenship pics
articles.summary: Today is Australia Day. Bendigos biggest event is at Lake Weeroona. Castlemaine will mark Australia Day-Survival Day at Victory Park. The temperature today is forecast to be 32 degrees with an extreme UV index. Tomorrow it's expected to hit a scorching 41 degrees.

articles.title: "NO HELP From FEMA": Volunteer SOUNDS OFF on Ongoing Hurricane Helene Disaster
articles.author: Status Coup News
articles.summary: Debora Bare is a volunteer helping with relief efforts after Hurricane Helene ravaged western North Carolina. Debora admits a lack of support from FEMA and other government agencies. Jason Peters interviewed Debora Bare in Burnsville, North Carolina about the ongoing disaster four months after Helene.

articles.title: Australia news live: thousands to gather at Invasion Day events across the country amid heatwave warnings
articles.author: Jordyn Beazley
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of protesters are expected to mark Invasion Day, or Survival Day, today with marches, rallies and gatherings for ceremonies and festivals across the country. In Western Australia, a string of bushfires has spread, which has seen homes lost and residents warned it is too late to evacuate. Today is the first day in the role as Australian of the Year for former AFL player and coach Neale Daniher. The Australian Open Mens' Final will take place this evening.

articles.title: Bunking climate science at Davos 2025
articles.author: Shaifali Sandhya
articles.summary: The California wildfires threatened the World Economic Forum leaders who were gathered at Davos. They are burning in the smouldering embers of the California wildfires. The world is in danger of a planetary apocalypse, they are warned.   Â

articles.title: Ranked: Land Animals With Longest Migrations
articles.author: Kayla Zhu
articles.summary: Voronoi app visualizes the longest known land animal migrations in kilometers. Caribou from the Bathurst herd and Porcupine herd recorded the longest terrestrial migration at 1,350 km. Gray wolves move the most over the course of a year.

articles.title: Is the world going nuclear? The hope and hype of nuclear as a climate solution
articles.author: political reporter
articles.summary: Nuclear attracted a lot of attention at the COP29 climate summit held in Baku, Azerbaijan late last year. Six more countries signed a pledge to triple nuclear's global production by 2050, taking the total number of countries on board to 31. Australia is about to head into a federal election with the adoption of nuclear power at the centre of the political contest.

articles.title: Joe Spagnolo: Why worry about being Australian and what does it mean as Australia Day arrives in 2025?
articles.summary: Joe Spagnolo asks why we should worry about being Australian as Australia Day arrives in 2025 and asks what does it mean to be Australian.      Â   in Joe Spagnol’s opinion,  in which he questions the meaning of Australia Day.

articles.title: Arctic-Boreal Zone's Unsettling Transformation into a Carbon Source Signals Dangers of Climate Change
articles.author: Ryan Whalen
articles.summary: Arctic-Boreal zone (ABZ) is rapidly transforming into a net carbon producer as climate change accelerates. 34% of ABZ emits more CO₂ than it absorbs. More vegetation means more CO2 being released through plant and microbial respiration. Increasing wildfires also affected the balance, further growing the carbon-producing acreage.

articles.title: B.C. Climate News: Europe posts record year for clean energy use as Trump moves to fossil fuels
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: According to the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, human activities like burning fossil fuels and farming livestock are the main drivers of climate change. The Earth is now about 1.3 C warmer than it was in the 1800s. The world is not on track to meet the Paris Agreement target to keep global temperature from exceeding 1.5 C.

articles.title: B.C. Climate News: Europe posts record year for clean energy use as Trump moves to fossil fuels
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: The Earth is 1.3 C warmer than it was in the 1800s. The world is not on track to meet the Paris Agreement target to keep global temperature from exceeding 1.5 C above pre-industrial levels. 97% of climate scientists agree that the climate is warming and that humans are the cause.

articles.title: Full list of UK seaside towns predicted to be underwater in 25 years
articles.author: Noora Mykkanen
articles.summary: The seaside towns of the UK are at risk of becoming submerged by 2050 due to climate change. The worst affected areas are on the coast and near estuaries in England and Wales, while Scotland's coastline is largely safe from rising water levels. The biggest driver of climate change is greenhouse gas emissions, which are a result of the burning fossil fuels.

articles.title: Full list of UK seaside towns predicted to be underwater in 25 years
articles.author: Noora Mykkanen
articles.summary: The seaside towns of the UK are at risk of becoming submerged by 2050 due to climate change. The biggest driver of climate change is greenhouse gas emissions, which are a result of the burning of fossil fuels. The worst affected areas are on the coast and near estuaries in England and Wales, while Scotland's coastline is largely safe from rising water levels.

articles.title: LETTER: Groundhog Day event in Victoria targets Big Oil
articles.author: Connie More
articles.summary: The state of California is suing Big Oil to recover climate change costs. In B.C., municipalities and regional districts can join a class-action lawsuit against Big Oil. Groundhog's Guide to Suing Big Oil is on February 2 at 2 p.m. at Broadview United Church, 3703 St. Aidan's St. in Saanich.

articles.title: Mega-iceberg drifts towards Antarctic penguin island
articles.author: Nick Perry
articles.summary: The world's biggest iceberg is more than twice the size of London. It is moving slowly from Antarctica on a potential collision course with South Georgia, a crucial wildlife breeding ground in the South Atlantic. A scientist warns it risks disrupting feeding for baby penguins and seals.

articles.title: Just Stop Oil activists caught boasting about defacing Charles Darwin's grave
articles.author: Max Parry
articles.summary: Alyson Lee, 66, a retired teaching assistant from Derby, and Di Bligh, 77, a former chief executive of Reading Council, were charged by police after Darwin's grave in Westminster Abbey was sprayed with orange chalk paint on January 14. The message '1.5 is dead' was scrawled on the memorial to the scientist in reference to 2024 being the first year in which the average global temperature exceeded 1.5C above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: Warning anyone with bird's nest in roof with 'fine and 6 months jail'
articles.author: Alex Evans
articles.summary: It's illegal to damage or destroy a bird's nest in the UK under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981. RSPB urges people to allow birds to nest in their homes if they find a suitable place to do so. People who break the law could face a fine and 6 months in prison.

articles.title: Protests, parties and heatwave alert for Australia Day
articles.author: Rachael Ward
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of protesters are expected to take to the streets for Invasion Day rallies. Others are going to the beach or a BBQ to mark Australia Day. It's been a heatwave in Australia.       for the last few days.

articles.title: 10 rare animal species found only in Australia
articles.author: Lifestyle Desk
articles.summary: Australia is home to some of the most rare animals in the world. Nearly 80 per cent of plants, mammals, reptiles, and frogs are uniquely linked to Australia. Here are 10 of the rare animals found in Australia: Koalas, platypus, echidnas, emus, wombats, quokka, tree kangaroos, cassowaries, Tasmanian devil and numbats.

articles.title: Ketu South: Tidal waves displace residents of Salakope
articles.author: House
articles.summary: The tidal waves distraction started on January 16th and has destroyed properties in Salakope, Agavedzi and surrounding communities in the Ketu South Municipality of the Volta Region. Mr Eben Asar, the Head of Assessment Members of the Electoral Area, said over 100 people were displaced by the new tidal waves. He appealed to philanthropists, government authorities, individuals and cooperate organisations to prioritise the construction of a sea defense wall.

articles.title: Yolo County announces 2030 Climate Action and Adaptation Plan
articles.author: The Daily Democrat
articles.summary: Yolo County Board of Supervisors approved the 2030 Climate Action and Adaptation Plan on Dec. 3, 2024. Yolo County is already experiencing impacts from the changing climate and needs to take immediate action to reduce emissions and protect its residents, according to a press release.

articles.title: The 2°C difference
articles.summary: The Paris Agreement was ratified in 2015 by 196 countries. It aims to keep the rise in global temperature below 2°C and strive for a limit of 1.5°C by 2050. At the current rate of climate change, experts warn that this threshold could be breached in just over 20 years.

articles.title: 10 Facts About the Race to Combat Global Warming
articles.author: B.Sc. Jessica Taylor
articles.summary: We have less than a decade to limit global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. Over 80% of the world's energy requirements are still met by coal, oil, and natural gas. Over 3 billion people are living in regions where climate change looms large. Developing countries need urgent financial aid to cope with climate change. Urban areas produce 70% of global CO₂ emissions.

articles.title: BIRDING TODAY: Without conservation, agenda for birds would not benefit
articles.author: Deb Hirt
articles.summary: Birds are disappearing fast. Several policies were reauthorized in 2024. Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act is critical for getting funding for on the ground habitat restoration projects and migratory bird wintering grounds. America's Conservation Enhancement Act is necessary for wetland conservation efforts. The Farm Bill is important for farmers, ranchers, and forest managers.

articles.title: Thousands of cranes overwinter in central Nebraska: 'Past few years have been kind of crazy'
articles.author: Marjie Ducey
articles.summary: About 10,000 to 15,000 sandhill cranes have overwintered on a stretch of the Platte River from Wood River to Grand Island in central Nebraska for the second straight year. Normally, millions of birds make the trip from their summer grounds in the northern United States, Canada and Siberia to the southern U.S. and Mexico. This year, the average temperature this season has been 39.4 degrees, compared with previous season averages of 37.4. Kearney area has received a half-inch of snow compared with normal totals of 9.6. For Omaha, the total snow this season adds up to an inch.

articles.title: At hurricane site, Trump considers axing disaster agency
articles.author: Bitwize
articles.summary: US President Donald Trump visited North Carolina and California on Friday to visit people affected by hurricanes and wildfires. Trump has heavily criticised California Governor Gavin Newsom and other officials for the response to the wildfires that caused widespread devastation this month. Trump promised before the election to cut red tape and provide federal support in rebuilding homes devastated by Hurricane Helene in North Carolina.

articles.title: Reader's View: Prepare for a long and preposterous four years
articles.summary: Donald Trump is going to be president for four years. He wants to use economic pressure to force Canada to become our 51st state and rename the Gulf of Mexico the 'Gulf of America' because it has a nice ring to it. He also wants to take over Greenland and the Panama Canal.

articles.title: FEMA to host event in McDowell County to help farmers recover from Hurricane Helene
articles.author: Staff reports
articles.summary: One-day Agriculture Recovery Centers are planned to help North Carolina farmers recover from Hurricane Helene damage. The first locations are set for Buncombe, Henderson, McDowell and Watauga counties. Additional events are planned for Ashe, Avery, Burke, Mitchell and Yancey counties. All are open 9 a.m. to 6 p.m., and attendees should bring evidence of ownership of damaged or lost tools and equipment.

articles.title: Hurricane survivors who met Trump in North Carolina share president's words that stuck with them

He was a Contributing Author to the most recent set of IPCC reports as a subject matter expert on policy, communication and public engagement. On January 20, 2026, the Trump administration will effectively withdraw.

Franklin Graham, president and CEO of Samaritan's Purse, told Fox News Digital that he appreciates Trump's visit.

articles.title: John Wheeler: Recent up-and-down temperatures have been tricky to forecast
articles.author: In Louisiana
articles.summary: This week's up-and-down temperatures reveal a fascinating aspect of warm fronts in winter. With a warm front, the temperature at the surface is often a tricky forecast. Weather models are still not very good at accurately representing the intricate vertical layering of atmosphere. Forecasters rely on experience and careful analysis of the conditions.

articles.title: Researchers sound alarm over disastrous phenomenon: 'Significant implications for infrastructure damage'
articles.author: Rachel Beyer
articles.summary: The global temperature is rising and the impact on extreme weather events is becoming more apparent. Tropical cyclones are intensifying along with associated flooding. Under a scenario of 4 degrees Celsius (7.2 degrees Fahrenheit) of global heating, the flooding caused by tropical cyclones becomes significantly more severe. There is a 65% increase in areas affected by compound flooding.

articles.title: Commentary: The urgent need to protect the Apalachicola River
articles.author: Maya Shenefelt
articles.summary: The Florida Department of Environmental Protection plans to approve a drilling permit for Clearwater Land and Minerals, a Louisiana-based company. Apalachicola River, once a symbol of abundance and beauty, is now a battleground for our planet's future. Florida's economy is deeply intertwined with its environment, and the development of a pipeline through Apalachicola Bay will further damage the environment and the economy.

articles.title: The world is on track for between 1.9 and 3.7°C of warming by 2100
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Some progress has been made in limiting greenhouse gas emissions, but we are still on the path for high levels of global warming, says Dr. Andrew Hammond of the World Meteorological Agency.    "There is still a high risk of high global warming."

articles.title: Joy Moses-Hall: Magnetism lies behind sun's toil and trouble
articles.summary: Since 2020, sunspots have increased in number from fewer than one per month to over 200. Sunspots are the splotchy precursors of the solar flares and eruptions that can set the Earth's auroral hair on fire. The sun showed a witchier face in 2024.

articles.title: Jan 25: Egypt Faces Moderate Weather on Saturday, Cairo 20°C
articles.author: Rana Atef
articles.summary: The Egyptian Meteorological Authority predicts moderate weather to prevail in Cairo, Lower Egypt, North Coast, and North Upper Egypt during Saturday's daylight hours. It is also expected that maritime navigation will be disrupted in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Suez with winds averaging 40 to 60 km/h and waves ranging between 2:3 meters. Extremely cold weather is expected in Egypt in the early hours and at the end of the nighttime.

articles.title: Welcoming climate envoys
articles.summary: Dale Webber was appointed as Jamaica's climate envoy. Dr James Fletcher was appointed to a similar position in the Caribbean Community. The region is paying a disproportionate price for the consequences of global warming. Developed countries have failed to meet their commitments on the emissions front and they are reluctant to provide the financing to help developing countries prepare for climate change.

articles.title: Opinion: Coastal living may endanger your life
articles.author: Kristina Carvalho
articles.summary: Rising sea levels and stronger storms are increasing the threat to coastal living. About 40% of the U.S. population, 128 million people, live in coastal counties. Health risks have skyrocketed for those living on the coast, especially for people of color and low-income people.

articles.title: Opinion: Coastal living may endanger your life
articles.author: Kristina Carvalho
articles.summary: Kristina Carvalho, MSW, is a policy analyst at the Boston University School of Public Health and a climate action volunteer with Sierra Club Maine. articles.author: ERIC WASHBURN
articles.summary: In 2023, 198 nations agreed to transition away from fossil fuels. In 2024, a handful of oil-producing countries, led by Saudi Arabia, tried to rescind the pledge. Saudi Arabia makes billions of dollars from oil sales annually. Chronic Wasting Disease (CWD) is the biggest threat to the future of deer hunting in Colorado. CWD is now in 34 states. Colorado's outdoor economy supported 132,594 jobs in 2023.

articles.author: Emily Whiting

articles.author: BILL CRANE
articles.summary: Greenland is the world's largest island. It is located between the North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans. Greenland is one of two autonomous territories of the Kingdom of Denmark. The capital and largest city is Nuuk. Most of Greenland's population lives near its southwest coast.

articles.author: Ron Sadler Las Vegas
articles.summary: Scientists say 2024 will be the hottest year on record due to human-caused climate change. Wildfires are burning hotter and moving faster, storms are getting bigger and carrying more moisture, and soaring temperatures worldwide are leading to heat waves and drought. In Europe, extreme heat contributed to at least 47,000 deaths in 2023. In the United States, heat-related deaths have doubled in recent decades.

articles.title: Made it through another year
articles.author: C.J. Geotis
articles.summary: It's winter. Most of his fishing buddies agree this was not one of their favorite years. The good thing is that nature is cyclic and multispecies fishing trips are on the way. It's good to think about 'the good old times'.

articles.author: Aarik Long
articles.summary: Haywood County School's school nutrition staff lost a lot of food this year due to weather-related closures. Hurricane/Tropical Storm Helene closed the school for 11 days in September. Many of the staff members were out of work as a result.

This was Trump's first trip outside Washington since his inauguration. Trump also criticized Democrats for abandoning hurricane-hit North Carolina and suggested a potential dismantling of FEMA.

articles.title: Odisha Sees Hottest January in 52 Years, Koraput Scorches at 33.2°C
articles.author: Ananya Pattnaik
articles.summary: Koraput district in Odisha is experiencing the highest January temperature in 52 years. Meteorologists attribute the extreme heat to climate change and shifting weather patterns. articles.title: Argonne National Lab researching links between weather in Chicago and the Arctic
articles.author: Tara Molina
articles.summary: It was colder in Chicago this week than in the Arctic. Scientists at Argonne National Laboratory in Lemont are studying the connection between the two places. articles.summary: Economic losses from natural disasters in the U.S. last year were $217.8 billion. Hurricanes Helene and Milton caused $75 billion in economic losses. Global insured losses, meanwhile, climbed 15.1% to $145 billion. Global losses from disasters were $368 billion last year.

He was addressing a Gender-responsive Climate Smart Agriculture and Food Systems workshop on Thursday at the Spanish Court Hotel in New Kingston. The initiative is a Can$10.5-million four-year project that runs from 2024 to 2028.

articles.title: 242 million children's schooling disrupted by climate shocks in 2024: Unicef
articles.author: NEWS WIRE
articles.summary: Extreme weather disrupted the schooling of about 242 million children in 85 countries last year. articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: The world's largest iceberg is moving slowly from Antarctica to South Georgia. It is more than twice the size of London and could run aground and threaten penguins and seals. Icebergs have grounded there in the past and killed penguin chicks and seal pups.

articles.title: Rural areas are harder hit by climate change. These communities are rising to the challenge

articles.title: Better digital literacy could help reduce climate and disaster conspiracy theories
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: In recent years, the proliferation of conspiracy theories amid climate disasters and their aftermath has become an alarming trend. During the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season in the United States, misinformation and disinformation regarding Hurricane Helene and Hurricane Milton proliferated on social media, as well as regarding Hurricane Milton.

articles.title: Whitehouse Statement on Trump's Visits to North Carolina, California Communities Devastated by Climate Change (US Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Donald Trump should not hold disaster aid hostage to his political whims, dismiss the climate crisis as a hoax, or pander to his Big Oil donors, says EPW Ranking Member Washington, D.C.-U.S. Senator Sheldon Whitehouse (D-RI).

articles.title: Mass travel underway for Lunar New Year
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: The world's biggest annual migration of humans is underway as mass travel in China reaches a peak in the last weeks of the year. China is home to the largest number of people in the world.      Â   in China.

articles.title: Let's fight climate change before it's too late
articles.author: Mankato Free Press
articles.summary: A changing climate is one of the main issues we think about and deal with on a daily basis. It would be great if a changing climate wasn't one of them. It's a problem that needs to be dealt with. It is a threat to human existence.

articles.title: CO2 pipelines part of dangerous climate agenda
articles.author: The Gazette Cedar Rapids
articles.summary: The Gazette offers audio versions of articles using Instaread. Some words may be mispronounced. Ted Turner warned in 2008 that in 10 years the earth could be too hot to grow crops and cannibals will eat people.    "Rising seas could obliterate nations by 2000".

articles.title: California, We Feel Your Pain Here in Australia
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: In California's fire-stoked debate over how to manage nature and urban sprawl, Australia can share both empathy and insight with the state, says Dr. Richard Branson.   "California is in a state of emergency. It's a very serious matter."

articles.title: Paris Agreement: Present tense, future dangerous
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: Donald Trump's decision to withdraw the U.S. from the climate deal is a blow to the available efforts to fight climate change in a warming, divided world. Most countries have to take steps to limit the temperature increase to be part of the climate agreement.

articles.title: The Original Aboriginals
articles.author: Quillette
articles.summary: Australia was the last continent to experience the Agricultural Revolution. Since humans have been hunter-gatherers for most of our existence, there is value in studying the peoples who inhabited pre-agricultural Australia. There is a lack of consensus over what we should call them.

articles.title: Trump's visit to Los Angeles foreshadows massive attacks on social programs, democratic rights
articles.summary: Donald Trump visited Hurricane Helene-affected Asheville, North Carolina and wildfire-devastated Los Angeles on Friday. Trump's tour is a warning that the ruling class in the US will not allow any disaster to go to waste and will seek to benefit from it. Trump has denied the reality of climate change, rolled back environmental protections and slashed funding for disaster response. He suggested that FEMA's role should be assumed by a marriage between state and religious charity organizations.

articles.title: Midwinter survey shows jump; total duck Count below 1 million
articles.summary: Arkansas Game and Fish Commission's annual Midwinter Aerial Survey shows a jump in ducks and mallards from estimates from early December. The survey also shows a rise in the number of ducks and mollusks from estimates a year ago in the state.
